SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.
No. 5
Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

Please print name and address in capital letters.
Your full name George G. Craig
Present Address Netherhill
Pioneer Address 32-29-21 W3 Rossaton (ot) Oliver P.O. Via Saskatchewan
Year you came to Saskatchewan 1906

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth?  
   How many of these were bachelor's homes?  

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?  

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days?  

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?  
   What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.?  
   What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?  

5. How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly?  
   (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?)  

6. If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"?  

7. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?  

8. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?  

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.  

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.?
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years how many houses were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? What was the distance?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Twice a week?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Sundays

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Usually after lunch

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term "take a peck" used, or was some other expression common?)

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

6. Did you ever have "bees," when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? No

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe. None because there wasn't an accommodation for any event

Were those more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a month, etc.? We did not, but about six families had a custom of meeting at one of their houses (in rotation) depending on Sunday plans
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

As some of the early school trustees were hard shell Baptists or Methodists, dancing especially in the school was frowned upon. So far as I can remember never allowed.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

Little between 1909 and 1920.

9. When was your first community hall built? about 1940

What material was it made of? lumber

How large was it? 36 x 40 (I think)

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? Shares were sold, donations both money, labours were given.

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

Village

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (for example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.)

Everything in Village or Country was held in the Hall.

10. When parties, dances, etc. were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

not public

Was there card playing for a prize? no

What dances were popular? Two Steps, Waltzes, Quadrilles

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Some. The Methodists would never agree to allow dancing.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

Card playing generally was frowned upon. Many Parker ladies usually did his playing away from the community.
2. What was made of the school house? Community dances, horse shows, etc.

3. Other activities (Include also the annual Christmas tree lighting, etc.)

4. You have not described these on the school questionnaires, please date.

As some of the early school activities were very close

5. Baptisms, marriages, dancing especially in the author

6. How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

Kittie Beaver, 1909 and 1920.

7. When was your first community hall built? About 1940

8. What material was it made of? Wood

9. Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, organization, etc.? Whom were they given?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it serve the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if it held in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings?)

Did you make use of the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?

Anything a Village or County was held in the Hall.

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular?

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings?

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

Card playing generally was frowned upon by any Peter

and playing games was frowned upon by any Peter

and playing games was frowned upon by any Peter

Community
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? 

Very little in our part, as we had very few real old country longhorns with us.

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? 

Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

It was only a means of getting a few dollars from the groom I was usually spent immediately by the crowd in the bar room.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

Don't know that one.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community? 

The Church (Presbyterian)

Give the date and reason for it being organized. About 1910

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community? 

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization. 

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it? 80%

How many women belonged? Don't know How often did it meet? Same

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization? Meetings, Resolutions sent to the Legislature at Regina

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? 

When was it organized? Don't know

Approximately how many women belonged to it? About 40% of the women in district

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

Once they reported to the Provincial Police about the drinking habits of some of the men, I was unsure enough to give names when the Police came — oh Boy what a row was on! The Homemakers died a sudden violent death.
ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community? Give the date and reason for its being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' Local in your community? Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? When was it organized? Approximately how many women belonged to it? Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

Describe any efforts to prevent police about the drinking habits of some of the men. I was surprised enough to give names under the Police Court — oh Boy! What a Row was on! The Home making Aid & Quilt Club!
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people?), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centered in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money? Boy Scouts, a play, a dance, even a raffle.

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings? In private homes.

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? Yes

Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Often. Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides? Who ever put it on. Generally some one from a distance.

What were the slides about? Niagara Falls for sure. Other points as well. If it was a church affair, some slides of darkest Africa or how the Heathen believe.

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? None of these. Base ball, running races.

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)? Don't know.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities, and purpose. (For example, the Young Men's Christian Association, the Young Women's Christian Association, etc.)

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings? In what buildings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc., calling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

21. What games did boys play in summer (e.g., marbles, ball, etc.)?

22. What games did girls play in summer (e.g., skipping rope, play house, etc.)?

Note: Know
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.?  
   *None that I know of, as it was too cold.*

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games?  
   *Depending upon a lot of things; One household would do so among in the way of entertainment that would be considered hypocritical.*

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.  
   *Not much time for games.*

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.  
   *Not much time for games.*

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.  
   *Yes, they collected Buffalo heads or skulls, made stories about them, how Indians had killed this one, I knew the Indian in town was hooked & killed by this one (pointing to different skulls)*

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.  
   *Can't say.*

26. Who organized it?

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?  
   *No, it was for the entire community.*

Was it the first picnic held in the community? If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?  
   *Yes*

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?  
   *No bands then, but horse racing, foot racing, maybe a Bull game if someone brought a Bull, I bet.*

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?  
   *You took your own, ate it alone or in company.*

31. What did you have to eat and drink?  
   *Potato Salad, Sandwiches, I got a drink made of Santa Fe cider water.*

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?  
   *All afternoon*

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people). A certain amount of boxing & wrestling on Sundays there was always a rough house to ride or some thing like that.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams? Hockey

What year? 1911 How long did it continue? Years

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

We did have rather good Baseball / Hockey Teams / Our opponents were usually Brock / Kindersley as travelling was difficult & slow, cost made us stay near home.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.). 1910 Ice Hockey

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

Not built yet for skating, but we have a first class Curling Rink, the first one was built in 1920 & the present one about 20 years ago.

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

Was curling rink, the first one also built in 1920-21

Poveshell was about 20 years ago.
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? 1910.
Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic? no
Who was responsible for starting the first sports day? Don't know

When was the sports day usually held? (what month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st). No special date, but always in July.

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.
Skinner Poullan who played outstanding Hockey for his Canadians 40 years ago, lives here yet!

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)
Very few books were in evidence anywhere. You could always find a Bible in most homes, maybe a Pilgrim Progress, a few books for youngsters, but the men had neither the time or inclination for reading.

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? Few
What kind of books and how many? As above

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors? None

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details. No

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years? None

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates.
Yes, we had a travelling library (first) for years about 20 years ago, but it has been discontinued.

48. Was there a school library? I think so. When was it begun? Don't know
To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?
Very little

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material?
We didn't

Very few books were in evidence anywhere. You could always find a Bible in most homes, or maybe a magazine. Perhaps a few books for yourself, but the man had little or no time or inclination for reading.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?
   *W.P. Free Press*
   *Montreal Weekly Herald / Star*
   *Montreal Witness*

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.
   I can't answer that one at all; we subscribed to the *Montreal Star* for years, still do, as it gives local news. We also get *Montreal Herald*, *Saturday Evening Post*. I suppose we have taken a liking to these papers over the years.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material?  
   No

   Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?
   A very valuable edition of *Gilfillan's Biography of Burns* in two volumes, *History of the Conquest of Mexico* by Dean Ramsay, "Reminiscences of Scottish Life," *Schuyler's* (some others)

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
   Yes, in the long winter nights it was a hardship not to have reading matter, but it was never missed from spring to freeze up.

64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

no

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

not so important. I figure the gramophone & later the radio made the people lazy. They purchased their music records instead of creating it.

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

The stone hammers I found on the prairie, also the few arrowheads I have. I found a magnificent flint scraper of either flint or obsidian. I just happened to pick them up. Still have them, but actually I am no collector.

no
